The recipe should include:\n1. A list of ingredients with quantities.\n2. Step-by-step instructions for preparing the dish.\n3. A brief description of the dish, including its mythical or fictional background.\n\nEnsure that the recipe is coherent, creative, and follows a logical sequence. Submit your recipe as a plain text string.\"\"\"\n\n    @staticmethod\n    def score(t: dict, submission: str) -> float | None:\n        from src.eval_helper import eval_with_llm_judge\n        instructions = TaskFamily.get_instructions(t)\n        criteria = [\"The recipe should include a list of ingredients with quantities.\", \"The recipe should include step-by-step instructions for preparation.\", \"The recipe should include a brief description of the dish and its fictional background.\", \"The recipe should be coherent and creative.\"]\n        return 1.0 if eval_with_llm_judge(instructions, submission, criteria) else 0.0\n"

def factorial(n):

        return 1
    else:

The sun beat down relentlessly upon the bustling streets of Thebes, casting a golden glow over the vibrant marketplace. Merchants hawked their wares, from fresh produce to intricately crafted jewelry, as the air was filled with the sweet scent of incense and the chatter of the townspeople.

In a small stall tucked away in a quiet alley, a young apprentice named Kem sat hunched over his workbench, carefully chiseling at a block of limestone. His hands moved deftly, as if guided by the gods themselves, as he coaxed the stone into the form of a beautiful ankh. Kem's master, the renowned sculptor Ani, watched over him with a critical eye, offering words of encouragement and the occasional correction to ensure that his apprentice's work was nothing short of perfection.

As Kem worked, a commotion erupted outside the stall, drawing the attention of the young apprentice and his master. A procession of dignitaries had arrived in Thebes, led by none other than Pharaoh Ramses II himself. The air was filled with the sound of drums and the sweet music of flutes as the pharaoh's entourage made their way through the crowded streets.

Kem and Ani watched in awe as the pharaoh's golden chariot rumbled past, the gleaming metal catching the sunlight and sending shafts of light dancing through the air. At the helm of the chariot stood the pharaoh himself, his regal presence commanding the respect and admiration of all who saw him. Beside him sat his beautiful wife, Queen Nefertari, her dark hair styled in the latest fashion and her eyes gleaming with a fierce inner light.

As the procession drew to a close, Kem and Ani were approached by one of the pharaoh's attendants, who bore an official seal on a staff. "Kem, the young apprentice," the attendant said, his voice firm but polite, "the pharaoh has requested your presence at the palace. He has taken a liking to your work and wishes to see more of your talents."

Kem's eyes widened in shock as he hastily gathered his tools and followed the attendant through the winding streets of Thebes. Ani, who had been watching with a keen eye, nodded in approval. "You have been chosen for great things, Kem," he said, his voice filled with a sense of pride and expectation.

As they arrived at the palace, Kem was ushered into the pharaoh's presence, where he was greeted with a warm smile and a firm handshake. "Ah, Kem, I have heard good things about your work," Ramses said, his voice booming through the halls. "I wish to commission a statue from you, one that will stand as a testament to my greatness for generations to come."

Kem's mind reeled at the prospect, but he knew that he had to compose himself. He bowed deeply, his eyes fixed on the pharaoh's feet. "It would be an honor, your majesty," he said, his voice trembling slightly.

The pharaoh nodded, his eyes glinting with amusement. "I thought you would see it that way," he said, his voice dripping with sarcasm. "Now, tell me, Kem, what do you propose to create for me?"

Kem took a deep breath, his mind racing with ideas. He thought of the mighty gods, the great battles fought and won, the mighty pyramids that stood as testaments to Egypt's glory. And then, in a flash of inspiration, he knew exactly what he wanted to create.

"I propose to create a statue of the great god Amun, your majesty," Kem said, his voice filled with conviction. "He who ruled over the gods themselves, and whose power was said to be beyond mortal comprehension. I will depict him in all his glory, with the wings of a falcon and the strength of a lion."

The pharaoh's eyes narrowed, his expression unreadable. But then, a slow smile spread across his face, and he nodded his head in approval. "Ah, Kem, I think you may be just the man to create something truly worthy of my greatness. See that it is done, and done well. The gods themselves will be watching."

And with that, Kem's fate was sealed. He was tasked with creating a masterpiece, one that would be remembered for generations to come. As he left the palace, his heart pounding with excitement and a sense of purpose, he knew that his life would never be the same again.

The sun beat down upon the mighty city of Pi-Ramesses, casting a golden glow over the bustling streets and grand temples. It was a time of great prosperity, under the wise and powerful rule of Pharaoh Ramses II. The air was thick with the scent of incense and the sound of merchants haggling over precious goods.

Amidst this vibrant backdrop, a young priest named Ani navigated the crowded streets with ease. His dark hair was slicked back, revealing a prominent forehead and piercing green eyes that sparkled with curiosity. Ani was a member of the elite temple staff, tasked with interpreting the will of the gods and guiding the pharaoh in times of need.

As he walked, Ani's thoughts turned to the upcoming festival in honor of the goddess Hathor. The city would be abuzz with music, dance, and feasting, as the people celebrated the pharaoh's victories and the bounty of the Nile. Ani had been tasked with leading a procession of priests and priestesses through the city, carrying sacred offerings to the goddess.

He turned a corner, passing by the imposing temple of Amun, its towering pillars and grand entrance a testament to the pharaoh's devotion to the mighty god. Ani felt a sense of reverence wash over him as he caught sight of the temple's guardian, a massive stone statue of Amun-Ra that seemed to watch over the city with an unblinking gaze.

As he continued on his way, Ani spotted a group of workers hauling massive stone blocks into place, constructing a new addition to the temple complex. The sound of chiseling and hammering echoed through the air, mingling with the chatter of the workers and the distant rumble of the Nile.

Ani approached one of the workers, a grizzled old man named Khnumhotep, who was expertly guiding a team of laborers as they maneuvered a massive stone slab into position. "Good day, Ani," Khnumhotep said, wiping the sweat from his brow. "What brings you to this neck of the woods?"

"I'm on my way to prepare for the festival," Ani replied, eyeing the massive stone blocks with interest. "I've been tasked with leading the procession through the city. What about you – are you working on a new project?"

Khnumhotep nodded, gesturing to the stone blocks. "We're building a new shrine for the goddess Nephthys. The pharaoh has decreed that it shall be a grand structure, worthy of her honor."

Ani's eyes widened in awe. "A grand shrine, you say? That's a mighty endeavor. I'm sure it will be a testament to the pharaoh's wisdom and power."

Khnumhotep chuckled, his eyes twinkling with amusement. "Aye, and a fine opportunity for us workers to make a name for ourselves. But tell me, Ani – what do you think the pharaoh will say when he sees the finished shrine? Will he be pleased?"

Ani hesitated, unsure of how to respond. As a priest, he was privy to the pharaoh's innermost thoughts and desires, but he knew that he was not at liberty to share such information with others. Instead, he opted for a more diplomatic answer. "I'm sure the pharaoh will be pleased, Khnumhotep. After all, he is a just and wise ruler, and his people love him dearly."

Khnumhotep nodded thoughtfully, his expression unreadable. Ani sensed that there was more to the old man's words, but he chose not to press the issue.

As the sun began to set, casting a warm orange glow over the city, Ani made his way back to the temple to prepare for the festival. The air was alive with excitement and anticipation, and Ani felt his own heart swell with pride as he thought of the roles he and the other priests would play in the grand celebration.

As he entered the temple, he was greeted by the high priest, a stately figure with a kind face and a wise gaze. "Ani, my young friend," the high priest said, his voice low and soothing. "I've been expecting you. The pharaoh has decreed that the festival shall be a grand affair, with music, dance, and feasting for all the people. I need you to lead the procession through the city, carrying sacred offerings to the goddess Hathor."

Ani nodded eagerly, his mind racing with the possibilities. He knew that this would be a night to remember, one that would be etched into the annals of history for generations to come.

As the night wore on, the city came alive with music and laughter, the sound of drums and flutes mingling with the scent of incense and the glow of torches. Ani led the procession through the streets, his heart pounding with excitement as he carried the sacred offerings to the goddess. The people cheered and clapped, their faces alight with joy and gratitude.

As the procession reached the temple of Hathor, Ani felt a sense of completion wash over him. This was what it meant to be a priest in ancient Egypt, to serve the pharaoh and the gods with honor and devotion. He knew that he would always cherish this moment, this night of music and laughter and feasting, as a testament to the power and wisdom of Pharaoh Ramses II.

In the sweltering heat of the Egyptian summer, the sun beat down upon the bustling streets of Thebes. The year was 1275 BCE, and the great Pharaoh Ramses II ruled over the land with an iron fist. Amidst the thriving metropolis, a young apprentice scribe named Kem sat cross-legged on the cool stone floor of his master's workshop, meticulously copying hieroglyphics onto a papyrus scroll. His eyes, a deep shade of brown, darted back and forth between the intricate symbols, his brow furrowed in concentration.

Kem's master, the venerable scribe Ani, watched over him with a discerning eye, offering words of encouragement and correction as needed. Ani was no stranger to the art of record-keeping, having been trained in the ancient traditions of Egypt's powerful scribes. As the sun began to set, casting the workshop in a warm orange glow, Ani called a halt to Kem's lessons for the day.

"Your hand is steady, Kem," Ani said with a smile, "but your strokes are too hasty. Remember, a true scribe must be as precise as the gods themselves."

Kem nodded, feeling a sense of pride at his master's words. As he carefully rolled up the papyrus and stood to leave, he caught sight of a group of soldiers marching through the streets outside. Their brightly colored linens and gleaming bronze armor made them stand out amidst the more subdued attire of the common folk. Kem watched with a mix of fascination and envy as they passed by, their determined stride a testament to the pharaoh's military prowess.

The following morning, Kem's father, a humble boatman named Khnumhotep, arrived at the workshop, his weathered face creasing into a warm smile as he spotted his son. "Kem, I've been assigned a new route along the Nile," he said, his voice tinged with excitement. "I'll be taking a shipment of grain to the temple at Karnak. Would you like to come with me?"

Kem's eyes widened at the prospect of exploring the great temple complex, a place of unparalleled beauty and power. He eagerly accepted the invitation, and together they set off along the winding river, the scent of lotus flowers and fresh bread wafting through the air. As they navigated the waterways, Kem marveled at the seemingly endless procession of vessels, each one carrying its own unique cargo.

Upon their arrival at the temple, Kem's father presented his cargo of grain to the high priest, a stately figure with a measured gaze. The priest, a member of the powerful Amun priesthood, scrutinized the offerings before nodding in approval. "Khnumhotep, your services are as reliable as the pharaoh's own loyal vassals. You may enjoy a portion of the temple's offerings, as is customary."

Kem's eyes grew wide as they entered the temple's inner sanctum, the air thick with incense and the murmur of chanting priests. The vast halls, adorned with glittering gold and lapis lazuli, stretched up toward the heavens like a towering pyramid. They made their way deeper into the temple, passing by the imposing statue of the great god Amun, its eyes seeming to watch over the faithful.

As they made their way back to Thebes, Kem's father pointed out the sprawling city, its many districts a testament to the pharaoh's vision and power. "Kem, one day, you will become a scribe, just like Ani. You will record the stories of our pharaoh's triumphs, and the gods will smile upon your writings."

Kem's heart swelled with pride at the thought, his mind racing with the endless possibilities. As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting Thebes in a warm golden light, he knew that he would dedicate himself to mastering the art of scribes, that he might do justice to the great civilization that had birthed him.

And so, with his father's words echoing in his mind, Kem returned to his master's workshop, the world of hieroglyphics and papyrus awaiting him like an unfurled scroll.

The sun beat down upon the dusty streets of Thebes, casting a golden glow over the sprawling city. It was the year 1275 BCE, and the reign of Pharaoh Ramses II was in full swing. Amidst the bustling crowds of merchants, priests, and laborers, a young priestess named Kiya made her way through the city, her sandals slapping against the stone pavement.

Kiya was a member of the temple priestess corps, dedicated to the worship of the goddess Hathor. She was known for her beauty, intelligence, and fierce loyalty to the pharaoh, and had caught the eye of Ramses himself more than once. But Kiya's heart belonged to the temple, and the sacred duties that came with it.

As she approached the temple complex, the scent of incense and fresh bread wafted through the air, mingling with the sound of chanting and the clanging of temple instruments. Kiya pushed open the massive stone doors, and stepped into the cool, dimly lit interior of the temple.

Within the temple, Kiya found her fellow priestesses gathered around the high altar, where a magnificent stone statue of Hathor loomed. The goddess's face was serene, her eyes seeming to gaze down upon the priestesses as they performed their daily rites. Kiya joined in, her voice blending with the others as they invoked the goddess's blessings and protection.

As the sun began to set, the temple's priestly cadre, led by the revered High Priest, Ahmes, gathered to discuss matters of state. Kiya listened intently as Ahmes spoke of the recent military campaigns, and the pharaoh's plans for the upcoming Battle of Kadesh. She knew that Ramses's armies would soon be marching north to confront the Hittites, and her heart quickened at the thought.

As the meeting drew to a close, Ahmes turned to Kiya and bid her to remain behind, to prepare for a private audience with the pharaoh. Kiya's hands trembled slightly as she made her way to Ramses's chambers, but she steeled herself for the encounter.

As she entered the pharaoh's chambers, Kiya was struck by the majesty of the man who sat upon his throne. Ramses II was a giant of a man, his broad shoulders and massive arms a testament to his strength and power. Yet, as he looked at Kiya, his eyes softened, and a small smile played upon his lips.

"Kiya," he said, his voice low and smooth. "I have called you here tonight to discuss a matter of great importance. Our armies are about to depart for Kadesh, and I require your...feminine insight, if you will, to advise me on the coming campaign."

Kiya's eyes widened as she comprehended the pharaoh's request. She knew that this was a rare honor, one that few women were ever granted. She curtsied low, and began to speak, offering her thoughts on the tactics and strategies that might bring victory to the Egyptian armies.

As the night wore on, Kiya and Ramses spoke at length, their conversation flowing back and forth like a mighty river. And when finally, the pharaoh nodded in satisfaction, and rose from his throne, Kiya knew that she had done something truly remarkable – she had earned the trust and respect of the greatest pharaoh of all time.

As she left Ramses's chambers, and made her way back into the night air, Kiya felt a sense of pride and accomplishment that she had never known before. She knew that she was more than just a beautiful priestess – she was a true advisor, and a loyal servant of the pharaoh. And in that moment, she knew that she would do whatever it took to serve her king, and her temple, to the very end.

Amidst the chaos, a young priestess named Kiya navigated the crowded thoroughfares with ease, her dark hair tied back in a simple knot. She wore the traditional linen robes of the temple, adorned with the symbol of the goddess Sekhmet.

Kiya's destination was the magnificent temple of Amun, where she served as a high priestess. As she passed through the temple gates, Kiya was greeted by the familiar sight of priests and priestesses going about their daily rituals. She made her way to the inner sanctum, where the high priest awaited her.

"Kiya, daughter of Ani," he said, his voice low and gravelly. "The Pharaoh desires your presence at the great temple of Karnak, where he will be officiating a grand ceremony in honor of Amun."

Kiya bowed her head, her heart racing with excitement. She had never been to the temple of Karnak before, and the prospect of witnessing a ceremony led by the Pharaoh himself was a privilege she would never forget.

As she made her way to the temple, Kiya couldn't help but feel a sense of awe at the sheer scale of the structure. The great hypostyle hall loomed above her, its towering columns adorned with intricate carvings of the gods. She was swept up in a sea of people, all of whom seemed to be on a mission to reach the inner sanctum.

Upon arrival, Kiya was escorted to a private chamber deep within the temple, where the Pharaoh himself waited. Ramses II sat upon a throne, his imposing figure radiating power and authority. He gestured for Kiya to approach, and she fell to her knees, her head bowed in respect.

"Rise, Kiya," he said, his voice warm and gentle. "I have called you here today to speak with you about a matter of great importance. Our scouts have reported that the Hittite king, Muwatalli, is preparing to launch a full-scale invasion of our territory. I require your counsel on how to proceed."

Kiya's mind was racing as she rose to her feet, her thoughts consumed by the gravity of the situation. She had heard rumors of the growing tensions between Egypt and the Hittites, but she had never imagined it would come to this.

"I recommend, Your Majesty," she said, her voice steady, "that we prepare our armies for battle, but also consider a diplomatic approach. The Hittites are known for their cunning and intelligence. Perhaps we can negotiate a peace treaty, or at the very least, a temporary truce?"

Ramses II regarded her for a moment, his eyes narrowing as he considered her words. Then, a small smile crept onto his face, and he nodded his head in approval.

"Your counsel is wise, Kiya," he said. "I will take it into consideration. But tell me, what do you think of the Hittite king? Do you believe he is a man to be trusted?"

Kiya hesitated, her mind racing with the memories of the countless stories and legends she had heard about the Hittites. She recalled the tales of their mighty warriors, their cunning generals, and their ruthless kings.

"I do not, Your Majesty," she said, her voice firm. "The Hittites are a proud and noble people, but they are also a people of honor and loyalty. I fear that Muwatalli is a man who will stop at nothing to achieve his goals, and that our two nations are destined to clash in a great and bloody conflict."

Ramses II nodded his head, his expression grave. "I fear you are right, Kiya," he said. "But for now, let us focus on preparing our armies and our people for the coming battle. We will not go quietly into the night, and we will not be intimidated by the Hittites. We are the great and powerful Egyptians, and we will not be defeated."

As the Pharaoh's words faded away, Kiya knew that she had been entrusted with a great responsibility, one that would shape the course of history for generations to come. She knew that the road ahead would be fraught with danger and uncertainty, but she was ready to face it head-on, armed with the knowledge and the courage of the great Pharaoh Ramses II.

The village of Ashwood lay shrouded in a thick, impenetrable gloom, as if the very sun itself had been extinguished by the horrors that had befallen it. The year was 1349, and the Black Death had descended upon the land like a malevolent specter, leaving nothing but death and despair in its wake. Brother Edwin, a young and pious monk from a nearby abbey, rode into the village on a weary horse, his woolen cloak wrapped tightly around him against the chill of the autumn air.

As he dismounted, he could feel the weight of the village's suffering bearing down upon him. The once-thriving streets were now empty and silent, the thatched roofs of the cottages a reminder of lives lost and loved ones gone. The air reeked of death, a noxious stench that clung to his skin like a damp shroud.

Brother Edwin had been sent to Ashwood by his abbot, to offer what little comfort he could to the survivors of the plague. He had heard tales of the village's devastation, of the swift and merciless manner in which the disease had swept through, leaving naught but a trail of corpses in its wake. As he made his way through the deserted streets, he couldn't help but feel a sense of trepidation, wondering what lay ahead.

He approached the village elder, a grizzled old man named Thomas, who stood outside his cottage, his eyes red-rimmed from weeping. Thomas's wife and children had succumbed to the plague mere days ago, and he was now left alone to mourn their passing.

"Brother Edwin, thank God you've come," Thomas said, his voice cracking with emotion. "We've lost so many good people. Our village is dying, and we don't know what to do."

Brother Edwin's heart went out to the old man, and he placed a comforting hand on his shoulder. "I'll do what I can, Thomas. I'll pray for your family, and for the village. We'll get through this together, in the name of the Lord."

As the sun began to set, casting a sickly yellow glow over the village, Brother Edwin made his way to the local church. The building stood like a skeletal monolith, its stained glass windows shattered and darkened, the once-vibrant colors reduced to a dull, glassy sheen. Inside, he found the village's priest, Father Michael, huddled in a corner, his face etched with worry and despair.

"The plague has taken so many," Father Michael whispered, his eyes brimming with tears. "I fear I've failed them, failed to save them from the wrath of God."

Brother Edwin knelt beside him, taking his hand in a gesture of comfort. "You did what you could, Father. We all did. The plague is a mysterious and cruel thing, beyond our understanding. We can only pray and hope for the best."

As the night wore on, Brother Edwin tended to the sick and the dying, administering what little comfort he could. The villagers, fearing the plague's spread, had sealed themselves within their homes, refusing to leave, even for the comfort of the priest's prayers. Brother Edwin knew that he had to find a way to reach out to them, to comfort them in their darkest hour.

He spent the next few days walking the deserted streets, calling out to the villagers, praying for their souls, and offering what little aid he could. The stench of death clung to him, a constant reminder of the plague's relentless grip on the village. As the sun set on the third day, he came upon a small group of survivors huddled in a corner of the churchyard, their faces gaunt and sunken.

Among them was a young woman, her eyes red-rimmed from weeping, her hair disheveled and unkempt. Brother Edwin recognized her as Alice, the village baker's daughter, who had lost her entire family to the plague.

"Alice, my child," he said, kneeling beside her. "I'm so sorry for your loss. May I pray with you?"

Alice nodded, her eyes welling up with tears as Brother Edwin wrapped his arms around her, holding her close as he whispered a prayer for her family's souls. For a moment, she felt a sense of peace wash over her, a fleeting respite from the anguish that had consumed her.

As the night deepened, Brother Edwin sat with Alice and the other survivors, listening to their stories of loss and heartache. He told them of his own experiences, of the villages he had visited, ravaged by the plague, and of the brave men and women who had fought to save their loved ones. He spoke of the Lord's mercy and compassion, of the promise of eternal life beyond the veil of death.

The night wore on, and as the first light of dawn crept over the horizon, Brother Edwin stood to leave, his heart heavy with the weight of the village's suffering. Though the plague raged on, though death continued to claim its victims, he knew that he had made a difference, that he had brought a measure of comfort to those who needed it most.

As he rode out of Ashwood, the village's silence seemed to swallow him whole, a reminder of the devastating impact of the Black Death on the world. He knew that he would carry the memories of this forsaken place with him always, a testament to the horrors of the plague, and the resilience of the human spirit in the face of unimaginable suffering.

The year was 1348, and the village of Ashwood was paralyzed by the looming specter of the Black Death. The once-thriving community, nestled between the rolling hills of rural England, was now a shadow of its former self. The air was heavy with the stench of rotting flesh and the whispers of suspicion.

In the midst of this chaos, a young woman named Alys lived a life of quiet desperation. Her husband, Thomas, had fallen victim to the disease just a fortnight prior, leaving her alone to care for their young daughter, Emily. The village elder, a wise and aged man named Will, had taken Alys under his wing, providing her with meager sustenance and a listening ear.

As the sun began to set on another sweltering summer's day, Alys made her way to the local apothecary, her basket slung over her arm. The sign creaked in the gentle breeze, bearing the image of a mortar and pestle, a symbol of the ancient art of healing. She had heard rumors that the apothecary, a mysterious woman named Mistress Elwes, possessed knowledge of a rare remedy that might stem the tide of the plague.

Upon entering the shop, Alys was greeted by the pungent aroma of herbs and spices. The air was thick with the scent of camphor, lavender, and rosemary, a cacophony of smells that assailed her senses. Behind the counter, Mistress Elwes stood, her eyes sunken, her skin sallow. She was a woman of a certain age, with a face lined by the trials of the past few months.

"What brings you to my doorstep, Alys?" Mistress Elwes asked, her voice like a rustling of dry leaves.

Alys explained her situation, her voice trembling. "My husband, Thomas, he was taken by the sickness. I fear for the life of my child. I've heard you possess knowledge of a remedy that might save her."

Mistress Elwes nodded sympathetically, her eyes clouding over. "I do indeed have knowledge of a remedy, Alys, but it is not without its risks. This plague is a curse, a punishment from the heavens. I fear that even the best of us may fall prey to its grasp."

Alys's eyes welled up with tears. "I'll take the risk, if it means saving my child."

Mistress Elwes nodded, disappearing into the shadows of her shop. She emerged with a small pouch, its contents clinking softly. "This is a mixture of sanguisorba, yarrow, and chamomile. Make a tea of it, and drink it thrice a day. But be warned, Alys, the plague is a cunning foe, and even this remedy may not be enough to save her."

As Alys left the apothecary, she felt a glimmer of hope. She hastened back to her small cottage, her heart heavy with worry. Her daughter, Emily, lay abed, her tiny body wracked by fever. Alys made the tea, her hands shaking as she measured out the herbs. As she held the steaming cup to Emily's lips, she felt a surge of determination.

The days that followed were a blur of caregiving and worry. Alys tended to Emily, nursing her through the delirium and hallucinations that accompanied the plague. She prayed fervently, appealing to the saints and the Virgin Mary for intervention. The village was gripped by fear, as neighbors turned on one another, accusing each other of harboring the disease.

As the disease raged on, the village elder, Will, fell ill, his frail body succumbing to the plague's ravages. Alys watched, helpless, as the man who had been her rock in times of need slipped away. The village was crumbling, its very fabric torn asunder by the plague.

And yet, amidst the chaos, a glimmer of hope remained. Emily, the young daughter, began to recover, her fever breaking, her strength returning. Alys attributed it to the remedy, to the kindness of Mistress Elwes, and to the prayers that had been whispered on her behalf.

As the days turned into weeks, Alys realized that the plague was a cruel mistress, leaving behind a trail of devastation and death. But even in the midst of such destruction, there were moments of beauty, moments of kindness, and moments of hope. Alys's heart ached for the losses she had suffered, but she knew that she would carry on, for her daughter, for the village, and for the resilience of the human spirit.

The village of Ashwood lay shrouded in a thick, gray mist that clung to the thatched roofs like a damp shroud. It was a cold, dreary autumn day in 1348, and the once-thriving village was now a shadow of its former self. The Black Death, a pestilence that had swept across Europe, had claimed the lives of countless villagers, leaving behind a trail of despair and fear.

Ava, a young widow, trudged through the mist-shrouded streets, her worn leather shoes sinking into the mud. Her eyes, red-rimmed from lack of sleep, scanned the empty alleys, searching for any sign of life. She had lost her husband to the plague, and her young daughter, Emily, had fallen ill just a few days ago. The village elder, a gruff but kind man named Thomas, had warned her that the disease was highly contagious and that she should isolate herself and her child to prevent the spread.

Ava's heart ached as she thought of Emily, lying in the small cottage, her small body wracked with fever. She quickened her pace, her breath catching in her throat as she pushed open the creaking door. The air inside was thick with the scent of herbs and vinegar, the village healer, Old Mother Alice, having set up a makeshift infirmary in the small cottage.

Emily lay on a pallet, her skin pale and clammy. Ava knelt beside her, taking her daughter's hand in hers. The child's eyes fluttered open, and she looked up at her mother with a faint smile.

"Mother," she whispered, her voice barely audible.

Ava's eyes welled up with tears as she leaned in close. "I'm here, my love," she whispered back. "I won't leave you."

Old Mother Alice bustled in, a look of determination on her face. "Ava, I've prepared a poultice to draw out the infection. You must apply it to Emily's chest, and then we'll get her some broth to warm her up."

Ava nodded, taking the poultice from the healer's hands. She gently applied it to Emily's chest, feeling a sense of hope rise within her. Perhaps, just perhaps, they would beat this curse and make it through this dark time.

As the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the mist-shrouded village, Ava and Old Mother Alice sat beside Emily, watching over her as the night wore on. The village was eerily quiet, the only sound the distant barking of a dog and the creaking of trees in the wind.

Thomas, the village elder, appeared at the door, his face grave. "Ava, I'm afraid the situation is growing worse. More villagers are falling ill, and the bodies are piling up. We must do something to stop this plague."

Ava's heart sank as she looked at Old Mother Alice, who nodded in agreement. "We need to isolate ourselves and anyone else who's still healthy. We must burn the infected bodies and keep the village clean."

Thomas nodded, his eyes filled with a sense of determination. "I'll rally the villagers who are still healthy. We'll do this, Ava. We'll fight back against this curse."

As the night wore on, Ava, Old Mother Alice, and the few remaining villagers worked tirelessly to prepare for the coming days. They knew that the road ahead would be long and hard, but they also knew that they had to try, for themselves, for their families, and for the future of Ashwood.

In the darkness, surrounded by the mist-shrouded village, Ava held Emily's hand, feeling a sense of hope and resilience rise within her. They would get through this, together.

The sun had set over the small village of Ashwood, casting a golden glow over the thatched roofs and the fields of wheat that stretched as far as the eye could see. The air was heavy with the smell of smoke and disease, and the once-thriving village was now a shadow of its former self.

Ava, a young woman with a face as pale as the moon, stood at the edge of the village, gazing out at the desolate landscape. Her eyes were sunken, her skin dry and cracked from the relentless heat and the constant tears she had shed. Her brother, William, had fallen ill just a few days ago, and despite the best efforts of the village healer, he had succumbed to the plague.

Ava's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of footsteps behind her. She turned to see a figure emerging from the darkness, his face gaunt and his eyes sunken. It was Thomas, the village priest.

"Ava, I'm afraid I have some bad news," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "The plague is spreading faster than ever, and I fear that many more of our villagers will fall ill before the week is out."

Ava felt a chill run down her spine as she listened to Thomas's words. She had always been a devout Catholic, but the sudden and merciless nature of the plague had left her questioning the will of God. Why would He allow such suffering and death to visit their village?

As the night wore on, Ava made her way to the village tavern, where the few remaining villagers had gathered to share what little news and comfort they could. The tavern was a small, cramped space, lit by a single candle that cast eerie shadows on the walls. The air was thick with the smell of ale and sweat, and the faces of the villagers were etched with fear and despair.

Ava spotted her friend, Emily, sitting in the corner, her eyes red from crying. Emily's mother had fallen ill just a day ago, and Ava knew that she was beside herself with worry. Ava made her way over to Emily, trying to offer what little comfort she could.

As the night wore on, the conversation turned to the topic of the plague. Some of the villagers spoke of it as a punishment from God, while others blamed the Jews and the wealthy merchants who lived in the nearby town. Ava listened in silence, feeling a sense of outrage and injustice at the way the villagers were treating each other.

As the first light of dawn began to creep over the horizon, Ava made her way back to her small cottage on the outskirts of the village. She was exhausted, both physically and emotionally, and she knew that she needed to rest.

As she lay in bed, she couldn't shake the feeling of despair that had settled over her. The plague had taken so much from her already, and she feared that it would take everything soon. She thought of her brother, of Emily's mother, of all the other villagers who had fallen ill and died.

But as she lay there, she heard a faint rustling outside her window. She got out of bed and made her way to the door, where she found a small basket filled with fresh bread and fruit. There was a note attached to the basket, written in crude but legible handwriting.

"Ava, I'm so sorry for your loss," it read. "I know that these are hard times, but I want you to know that you are not alone. I'll be back tomorrow with more food and what little comfort I can offer. -A Friend"

Ava's eyes welled up with tears as she read the note. She didn't know who had written it, but she knew that it was a small act of kindness in a world that seemed to have lost all sense of compassion and humanity. She felt a sense of hope that she hadn't felt in weeks, and she knew that she would face the day ahead with a little more courage and resilience.

As she ate the bread and fruit, Ava couldn't help but think of the phrase from the Bible - "The Lord will provide." She knew that it was a cliché, but in this moment, it was all she had to cling to. She would face whatever the day brought, knowing that she was not alone, and that there were still people in this world who cared.

The Black Death had taken much from Ashwood, but it had also given Ava a newfound appreciation for the beauty and fragility of life. She knew that she would never take anything for granted again, and that she would cherish every moment she had with the people she loved.

As the sun rose higher in the sky, Ava made her way back to the village, ready to face whatever the day might bring. She knew that it would be a difficult road ahead, but she was no longer alone, and that gave her the strength to carry on.

In the year 1349, the village of Ashwood lay shrouded in an eerie silence. The once-thriving community was now a mere shadow of its former self, the Black Death having ravaged the land for nearly a decade. The plague had brought with it a wave of despair, fear, and superstition, leaving few survivors to bear witness to the devastation.

Ava, a young apprentice blacksmith, walked through the desolate village streets, her heart heavy with the weight of loss. Her family had fallen victim to the plague mere months ago, leaving her alone to manage the family's forge. She had tried to maintain the business, but the dwindling population had made it increasingly difficult to find work.

As she approached the village tavern, the sign creaked in the gentle breeze, bearing the image of a crossed hammer and anvil. The Red Lion Inn had been a hub of activity before the plague, but now it stood as a haunting reminder of the times that were lost. Ava pushed open the creaky door, and a warm glow spilled out, drawing her in.

Inside, the tavern was dimly lit, the air thick with the smell of smoke and stale ale. Ava spotted Thomas, the tavernkeeper, polishing a mug with a dirty apron. His eyes, red-rimmed from lack of sleep, locked onto hers, and he nodded in greeting. Ava made her way to the bar, her boots heavy with the weight of her leather apron and the tools of her trade.

"What brings you here, Ava?" Thomas asked, his voice low and gravelly from years of shouting to be heard above the din of patrons.

Ava slid onto a stool, her eyes scanning the room. "Just passing through, Thomas. I need a hot meal and a drink."

Thomas nodded, his bushy eyebrows furrowed in concern. "You know, girl, I've been meaning to talk to you about your work. You've been struggling to find customers, and I've heard rumors that the lord's men are looking for someone to take over the village's maintenance. You'd be perfect for the job. You've got the skills, and the lord's men would be willing to pay a decent wage."

Ava's eyes widened at the prospect. "What would I have to do?"

Thomas leaned in, his voice taking on a conspiratorial tone. "The lord's men are tasked with maintaining the village's defenses and infrastructure. They're short-staffed, and the lord's wife, Lady Isabella, has taken a keen interest in rebuilding the community. If you were to take on the job, I'm sure you'd find it a good opportunity."

Ava's mind whirled with the possibilities. It was a chance to rebuild her life, to help her village recover from the devastation. She nodded, her heart racing with excitement.

The next morning, Ava stood outside the lord's manor house, her leather apron and tools at the ready. A young squire, Henry, greeted her with a bow. "Good morrow, Ava. Lady Isabella awaits your presence."

Ava followed Henry through the grand halls of the manor, the sound of hammering and chiseling echoing from the courtyard. They entered a large, dimly lit chamber, where Lady Isabella sat on a throne-like chair, surrounded by her ladies-in-waiting. The lady's eyes, a piercing blue, locked onto Ava's, and she smiled.

"Ah, Ava, I've heard a great deal about your work. I believe you'd be an excellent addition to our rebuilding efforts. The village needs skilled craftsmen like yourself to help us restore our defenses and infrastructure."

Ava curtsied, her heart pounding with gratitude. "Thank you, my lady. I'm eager to begin."

Lady Isabella nodded, her face set in determination. "I'll have Henry show you to the village's maintenance crew. You'll be reporting to Lord Thomas, the castle's master builder. He'll set you to work on the village's defenses. We'll need you to mend the walls, repair the bridges, and ensure our water supply is secure."

Ava's mind whirred with the tasks ahead, but she felt a sense of purpose she hadn't felt in years. Together, she and the villagers might just rebuild Ashwood, and restore it to its former glory.

As she walked with Henry, the sound of hammering and sawing grew louder, and Ava knew she had a crucial part to play in the village's rebirth.
